body: Merged. Thanks!

Can you reframe the remaining problems as a new ticket?  The original GROOVY-9288 issue should be fixed in my estimation.

Also, you have test cases disabled with a boolean switch.  Can you use @Ignore or @NotYetImplemented to disable them?  And do you expect those test cases to work?  It was unclear if they indicate a different problem or unsolved part of the current issue.

Even if the fix for GROOVY-7996 was rolled back, protected field can not be accessed via `thisObject`, `owner` and `delegate` : https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/1046#issuecomment-546768985
So the original description of GROOVY-9288 have to be refined too.

@eric-milles Let's make it work, then work better, at last work perfectly ;-)

Replaced with https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/1050
@eric-milles  BTW, I will add your tweak in PR https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/1050 with your commit info reserved

@eric-milles After your patch applied, the following tests fails, so I will keep the original PR as it is for now:

As 72 hours has gone, I will merge the PR to avoid code conflicts.
Merged. Thanks!
Merged with some tweaks. Thanks.
Is this change specific to Groovy 2.4?  Groovy 2.5 only has ASM 7.1.

If 2.5 is already using ASM 7.1, then the bug is likely specific to 2.4, since the ASM bug was fixed in ASM 7.1 (see https://asm.ow2.io/versions.html). My colleague verified that 7.1 fixes the Groovy issue as well. Would you like me to switch the PR from 7.2 to 7.1 for consistency with the 2.5 branch?
Yes, 7.1 to be aligned with Groovy 2.5 would be my suggestion.

It's fine if you want to discuss or experiment with changes like this, but the idea has reached nothing close to consensus.  This would be a breaking change for anyone that has a CompileDynamic, CompileStatic or TypeChecked class already defined.
http://groovy.329449.n5.nabble.com/Re-apache-groovy-GROOVY-9296-GEP-Import-TypeChecked-CompileStatic-and-Compile-1056-tp5762000p5762002.html
Merged. Thanks.

@danielsun1106 Do you see any issue with this change?  Is there any reason Groovy 2.4 uses ASM 6 and Groovy 2.5 uses ASM 7 besides time?

@paulk-asert Is there a possibility of a minor Groovy 2.4 release for this and other small bug fixes?
It's OK to bump asm to 7.X, but it is a big bump, so we are not sure whether it will impact existing projects. Also, 2_4_X is not maintained any more unless some blocker issues are found.

This is a blocker issue for us, as far as being able to upgrade to 2.4.16 or 2.4.17, to get the bug fixes in those releases, particularly 2.4.16 which has several bug fixes for issues we have experienced. We are currently using an internal fork of 2.4.17 in production, which we obviously like to avoid.
Merged. Thanks!
Merged. Thanks!
+1. This looks like it is doing the right thing and appears to solve the manual test case in the jar attached to this issue.

When I have used a filesystem-based ibiblio in the past on Windows, the format looked like
```
<ibiblio name="Local" m2compatible="true" root="file:///C:/Users/..."
```
As stated above, `${user.home}` is going to resolve to "C:\..." on Windows and "/home/..." on Linux.  So, I don't think you can unconditionally set a file url prefix that will work for both.  Is there a variable that can be used to get a file: url for the user's directory?

Another approach would be to set the "ivy.ibiblio.default.artifact.root" property from the code and remove the root attribute from the settings file.  I think this defaults to Maven Central's URL.  So you would need to add a root attribute to the ibiblio below jcenter, which is intended to point to maven central.

https://ant.apache.org/ivy/history/master/resolver/ibiblio.html

Or you may be able to encode "user.home" to a url and set as a system property that is referenced from the default settings file.

Update: Looks like you can set variables for the settings file like this "ivyInstance.settings.setVariable('ivy.checksums', '')" instead of System properties.

Last line below is proposed addition to `GrapeIvy.groovy` that would allow you to use "${user.home.url}" in the default settings xml.
```groovy
    GrapeIvy() {
        // if we are already initialized, quit
        if (enableGrapes) return

        // start ivy
        Message.defaultLogger = new DefaultMessageLogger(System.getProperty('ivy.message.logger.level', '-1') as int)
        settings = new IvySettings()
        settings.setVariable('user.home.url', new File(System.getProperty('user.home')).toURI().toURL() as String)
```

_Note_: This property value ends with a slash.

Merged into GROOVY_2_4_X. Thanks. Feel free to close. The auto close feature only works for commits to master.
This is ready to review and merge.  I have tested with one of our Ant builds against Java 11.
Isn't the JDK providing [HttpClient](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.net.http/java/net/http/HttpClient.html), HttpRequest and HttpResponse as part of Java 11?

I think the `==~` operator is available for this purpose.  Slightly different semantic between `find()` and `matches()`, but find keeps searching for next match which is an expected/intended behavior.
The idea is to simplify code required to perform put/post/... Class created before java11.

@eric-milles, I wouldn't say that's the same use case. The JIRA issue focuses on a side effect that is caused by calling:

```
matcher as Boolean
```

Usually you don't expect that casting an object to some other type causes internal changes in the casting object. I agree that using `==~` operator is easier and safer to use, and this is what the guy who asked question on Stack Overflow eventually did. However, the question is still open - should `Matcher.asBoolean()` change the internal state of the object? It shouldn't in my opinion, and that is why this pull request was created. But it's up to you to decide if this makes sense or not.
I'm a +1 for this change as long as there is some way to communicate that the pattern of using the Matcher's Groovy truth value in a loop will require the addition of ".find()" in Groovy 3.
Merged. Thanks.
Merged. Thanks!
Merged. Thanks!
Are methods being made protected to make them callable or to make them overridable?  That is should any of the formerly private methods be made protected *and* final?

I would like to change current private methods implementation too. 

If I want to extend customizer I have to access private list of checkers too. I made them protected.
At this point, wouldn't it be better to export the parts you find valuable to an interface or utility class?  It is hard to understand why you need each and every field and method to be visible.

"export the parts you find valuable"
Do you mean copy and paste code into my interface? In that case I have to copy all tests related to valuable code.

What I mean is this: SecureASTCustomizer is a class that extends CompilationCustomizer.  If there are some select parts of SecureASTCustomizer that you wish to share, then move them into an abstract class that sits between SecureASTCustomizer and CompilationCustomizer or into an interface that SecureASTCustomizer implements.

By opening **all** the parts of SecureASTCustomizer to extension, you are completely removing the ability to enhance or refactor SecureASTCustomizer without the possibility of impacting extensions.

"without the possibility of impacting extensions."
That's true. 

Methods are already made protected in master. Checkers are still private (without getters) so I can overwrite method without access to checker. 
I am sorry for misunderstanding, but is there any class between SecureASTCustomizer <-> CompilationCustomizer? By interface you mean CompilationUnit.PrimaryClassNodeOperation.
Thank you for your time and answers.

No, there is not a class that sits between SecureASTCustomizer and CompilationCustomizer currently.  What I am suggesting is to add a class that does (instead of moving shared code up into CompilationCustomizer).  The interface idea also is suggesting creating something new.

Would you be willing to share you SecureASTCustomizer extension so that I can get a better idea of what is being shared or overridden?

As an addition to current SecureASTCustomizer I want to add
`doubleStartImportsWhitelist/Blacklist` to allow e.g. `java.io.**` whitelist/blacklist and for static imports too.
So there will be list of doubleStarsImports and I have to overwrite `assertImportIsAllowed`++

(implementation is in java)

Merged. Thanks. Please feel free to close this PR. I have left the Jira issue as is (reopened) since after the rollback, the initial example in the issue is breaking again even after this PR. Is that also your expectation? Perhaps we need to add that testcase in and marked as NotYetImplemented?
Merged. Thanks.
Since you only need to visit import nodes, wouldn't it be easier to create a new, standalone compilation customizer?  Is a "double star" import an enhancement to the language of yours?

I have to do that in that way now. So what I did is that I took whole code of ```SecureASTCustomizer``` and I added implementation of double stars checks into assertImportIsAllowed + similar methods and all associated setters.
Because it only extends the functionality of SecureASTCustomizer.

My pull request is based on changes already merged to Groovy v3. 

re:  Is a "double star" import an enhancement to the language of yours?
No, I have to restrict imports of classes and sub-packages .... + I have to keep standard imports configurations. That's why I have to use both.

Maybe I misunderstood.  Are you saying you want to blacklist or whitelist not just 1 package but an entire "tree" of packages?  Is that the significant difference from SecureASTCustomizer?  Could we just fix the existing class to support that?

The pull request is only about allowing overwriting of methods and accessing fields.

My final goal is to support double star convention. I can implement double stars in our custom code, but if you think it make sense to propagate this functionality to the groovy code base I'll be glad to create a pull request.

I would rather see an enhancement to SecureASTCustomizer that can benefit others than to see all of its members protected, which is of little or no benefit.  In my experience, asking a few questions about the motivation for changes often leads to solutions that are deeper and more widely beneficial.  Sorry if my questions seem strange; I was just looking for a way to move stale pull requests along.

Also this pull request is for the 2.6 branch, which is end of life.
@paulk-asert the PR fixes the issue caused by the fix for GROOVY-7647( https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/830 ), please review it.

Because you are removing the trailing "." and "*"s from the double-star form and then checking with `startsWith`, you will get false matches.  Example "java.**" will be truncated to "java" and `"javax.swing.Action".startsWith("java")` will be true.

>The Groovy 2.6 version of Groovy has been retired to focus on faster delivery of Groovy 3.0. 

see: http://groovy-lang.org/releasenotes/groovy-2.6.html

So you can focus your efforts on `3.0`.
How about using `CompilerConfiguration.DEFAULT.getTargetBytecode()` if there is no active configuration instead of adding another global constant?

Good idea.
I'm trying to fix the bytecode issues...

Weired...  Java9+ builds are green, but Java8 build failed...
```
groovy.ant.Groovy9105Test > testGenerateStubs FAILED
    java.lang.IllegalAccessError: tried to access method groovy.ant.AntTestCase.doInTmpDir(Lgroovy/lang/Closure;)V from class groovy.ant.AntTestCase$doInTmpDir
        at groovy.ant.AntTestCase$doInTmpDir.callCurrent(Unknown Source)
        at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.callsite.CallSiteArray.defaultCallCurrent(CallSiteArray.java:51)
        at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.callsite.AbstractCallSite.callCurrent(AbstractCallSite.java:156)
        at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.callsite.AbstractCallSite.callCurrent(AbstractCallSite.java:168)
```

@paulk-asert Please review the PR too :-)

So, I tried to keep from having extra constants added to CompilerConfiguration and now there are 3.  What is the purpose of `ASM_API_VERSION`, `ASM_COMPUTE_MODE` and `ASM_PARSE_MODE`?  Who would use them (that is whay are they in CompilerConfiguration and public)?  What is the new `CompilerConfiguration#getAsmTargetBytecode` for and why is it separate from `getTargetBytecode`?

I don't understand the motivation of all of these changes and there are now 18 files changed and a whole bunch of commits.  The issue just says "bump bytecode version".
